nodes.text: Main console: LOAD-SHED RESPONSE overlay, pinned atop shutdown verification UI. (pause) Yellow banner persists: DEMAND EVENT ACTIVE — RESPONSE REQUIRED. (pause) Under it, almost offended: VERIFICATION MODE: STABILITY REQUIRED.

Control Room. Utility Dispatch. (pause) Timestamp 14:22:04. (pause) Confirm you’re acting on the demand event. (pause) I need your action record ID. (pause) Send it once you have it. (pause) And state you’ll maintain stability. (pause) I need it stated.

Dont say emergency. (pause) Dont say well try. (pause) Just give them: acknowledge the demand event. (pause) initiating response. (pause) stability maintained per interlocks. (pause) Transcript wants it plain.
The console shows big, friendly buttons—liability: VIEW/LOAD MAP. PRINT ACTION-HEADER. CONFIGURE SHED. EXECUTE ROUTING.

choices.text: look: View load map and current critical/noncritical tags.
ask: What does “maintain stability” mean in this console?
use: Configure shed (staged vs single-step).
use: Print action header to the log tray.
persuade: Use OLEA standard wording (authorized signatory).
threaten: Cite the stability clause and request immediate escalation handling.
leave: Step away from the console.

nodes.text: Acknowledging demand event. (pause) Initiating load-shed response. (pause) Stability maintained per interlocks. (pause) Action record ID pending console header.
Accepted. (pause) Timestamp 14:22:11. (pause) Get me the record ID when it’s available. (pause) When first action hits, report shed start time.

Good. Keep it standard. (pause)
Now get the console to spit out (pause)
something attributable.
Under the stability clause I need escalation handling. (pause) And a logged directive. (pause) Confirm you want the shed executed now. (pause) Attributable and stable.
Noted, timestamp 14:22:14. (pause) Directive stands—execute shed now. (pause) No cycling. No step-load chatter. (pause) Then send record ID and shed start time.
Okay. (pause) Dont push it further. (pause) Confirm action, then print. (pause) I want something we can staple.
Escalate this. I’m not acting on undocumented orders.
Negative. (pause) Timestamp 14:22:16. (pause) It’s documented—recording and log mirror. (pause) Confirm action now. (pause) Don’t hold the shed up over process language.
Yeah, its recorded. (pause) Still need that header. (pause) Print it. Then act. (pause) Dont burn time polishing the wording.

The screen redraws into a block diagram: feeder names and breaker groups. (pause) Three load categories appear with mismatched fonts. (pause) CRITICAL lists chamber environmental and rotation frame lubrication. (pause) It also shows a box labeled VERIFICATION SUPPORT—unhelpfully most of the building.
VERIFICATION SUPPORT. Great. (pause) Checklist treats it like glass. (pause) Dispatch treats it like spare. (pause) Pick what you want to defend.

choices.text: ask: How much can I shed without touching “verification support”?
look: Inspect breaker group details (restart surge notes).
leave: Back to the console menu.

nodes.text: How much shed without touching verification support?
Three shed presets highlight. None meet the target alone.

We can shave a little (pause) without touching it. (pause) Twelve megawatts wont happen that way. (pause) To hit target clean, (pause) we reclass supportor (pause) we drop an auto-recover (pause) and Dispatch calls it a miss.

Several groups carry a warning: AUTO-RECOVER ENABLED. (pause) RESTART SURGE LIKELY. (pause)
A few are annotated in terse maintenance shorthand: “CHATTER RISK.” (pause) “THERMAL LAG.” (pause) “DO NOT CYCLE.”
Clear—if it auto-recovers, it’s not a shed. (pause) That’s delay. (pause) Avoid cycling. (pause) Avoid chatter. (pause) I need it stable. (pause) I need it attributable.
Define “maintain stability” in this console.

Stability: no surprise tasks I must name later. (pause) Voltage stays in band. (pause) No step-load chatter. (pause) No cycling. (pause) And don’t do anything undocumented. (pause) Legal cares about that part.
Undocumented. (pause) Thats the landmine. (pause) We can stage it with timestamps, (pause) or single-step it. (pause) The no-chatter macro is the one (pause) the checklist wont like.

choices.text: use: Configure a staged shed plan.
use: Configure a single-step shed.
leave: Back to the console menu.

nodes.text: A configuration pane opens: TARGET SHED 12 MW. (pause) Slider disabled. Presets only. (pause) Tabs: STAGED and SINGLE-STEP. (pause) Cursor blinks, like it wants a signature.
Staged buys you more timestamps. (pause) Single-steps cleaner electricallyand whoever clicks it, wears it.

choices.text: use: Select STAGED shed (multiple groups).
use: Select SINGLE-STEP shed (one macro).
leave: Back to the console menu.

nodes.text: The console assembles three staged groups. The third is marked: VERIFICATION SUPPORT — TEMPORARY RECLASS REQUIRED.
There it is. TEMPORARY RECLASS REQUIRED. (pause) Use an existing code. (pause) Dont invent a new bucket under pressure.
Confirm you’re acting. (pause) I don’t need the philosophy. (pause) I need a timestamp. (pause) And I need it stable.

choices.text: talk: Confirmed. Initiating staged shed.
use: Reclass “verification support” as noncritical (temporary).
leave: Back to the console menu.

nodes.text: Confirmed. Initiating staged shed.
Timestamp 14:22:31. Logged. (pause) Send the action record ID when it’s available. (pause) And report first-step time as it happens.
Good. Make the reclass airtight. (pause) Or theyll write cycling on you.

A dialog box appears with a legal tone and a petty request: SELECT JUSTIFICATION CODE. (pause)
The available codes are pre-filled. None are kind.
Pick a code that already exists. (pause) Dont write a new justification. (pause) That meeting doesnt go your way.

choices.text: use: Justification: GRID DIRECTIVE — DEMAND EVENT.
leave: Back to staged options.

nodes.text: VERIFICATION SUPPORT flips from CRITICAL to NONCRITICAL with no animation, like it’s ashamed.
Good. (pause) Put the classification update in the notesexact wording. (pause) Thats what survives.
The console offers one macro: EXECUTE ROUTING: ALIGNMENT-SEQUENCE LOAD ROUTING (12 MW CLEAN). (pause) Beneath it: NOTE: MAY ALTER VERIFICATION BASELINE. (pause) The word “may” is doing too much work.
Thats the one. (pause) Keeps the interlocks happy. (pause) Tightens up the rotation frames. (pause) Checklistll gripe about baseline. (pause) Just keep it documented.

choices.text: ask: Why does it say “alignment-sequence”?
use: Execute alignment-sequence load routing.
leave: Back to the console menu.

nodes.text: Why “alignment-sequence”?
Because Legal likes vague names. (pause) Operationally it balances load and syncs frames quietly. (pause) That's as far as we go.
Execute.

The console asks for final confirmation in all caps, like volume is authority. (pause)
ACKNOWLEDGE: ROUTING WILL INITIATE AUTOMATED ALIGNMENT CONTROL. (pause)
The confirm button is labeled: I ACKNOWLEDGE.

choices.text: talk: I acknowledge.
leave: Cancel and step back.

nodes.text: You back out. The macro remains highlighted, waiting like it knows you’ll return.
Timestamp 14:22:57. Confirm you’re acting. (pause) Confirm you’ll maintain stability.
Say it clean. Then eyes on the numbers.
Acting. Stability maintained per interlocks.
The console logs a new line item: ALIGNMENT CONTROL: ARMED. ROUTING: IN PROGRESS. (pause) In the corner, the small chamber camera feed stutters.

The containment sphere’s surface flickers—matte to reflective, reflective to matte—like a thought it mustn’t have. (pause)
The console continues counting down routing steps as if nothing visual is relevant.
Armed is a lousy word. (pause) Panel prints it, so we’ve got it. (pause) We enabled it. That’s all.
The log printer wakes with a reluctant whine. (pause) A strip curls into the tray. (pause) ACTION HEADER — CONTROL ROOM CONSOLE, serial and timestamp.
Good. Serial and timestamptheres your attribution. (pause) Keep it tied to the console record.

choices.text: show: Read back the header serial to Dispatch.
leave: Back to the console menu.

nodes.text: Action header serial CR-CON-0194.
Received, timestamp 14:22:19. (pause) Proceed. (pause) Report shed start time at first action.
You step back. The demand banner stays pinned, politely escalating at the edge of your vision.
Step out if you need air. (pause) Timestamp still runs. (pause) Come back. (pause) Bring papersomething we can staple.
